newsitem.title: USA: Maine tribe eyes Canadian ferry route for gambling.
newsitem.headline: Maine tribe eyes Canadian ferry route for gambling.

text.p: A Maine Indian tribe said it will bid for a Canadian government-owned ferry route between the state and Nova Scotia in an effort to expand its gambling operations, .

The Passamaquoddy tribe plan calls for replacing the M/V Bluenose, using a boat with larger casino facilities that could be used in the international waters of the Gulf of Maine, tribal officials said late on Wednesday.

The Bluenose, which runs between Bar Harbor and Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, is one of several ferry routes serving Maritime Canada that are being sold by Marine Atlantic in a bid to reduce government subsidies.

A Passamaquoddy spokesman said other parts of the proposal address expansion of the ferry route to include stops at several Maine ports and coordinate it with a planned expansion of passenger rail service.
Tribal officials, who did not disclose the financial terms of the offer, make up one of several groups expected to make proposals before the bidding deadline closes Tuesday.

Maine blocked a the tribe from building a casino on the border with New Brunswick, but no approval would be needed for a facility in international waters. Gambling is offered on the privately owned ferry between Portland and Mova Scotia.
